Award.AwardTitle: CRII: Cyberlearning: Teaching Intercultural Competence through Personal Informatics

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
The need for intercultural competence has never been higher as technology makes it easier for people to engage in global communications, collaboration, and commerce. In higher education, the global and multicultural environment means that the challenges of intercultural communication exist within classrooms. This project would study how technology can help STEM teaching assistants, especially foreign teaching assistants, better communicate with their students across cultural lines, by building and testing software called CANAR (Computer-Aided Noticing and Reflection). The ultimate goal is support better teaching and learning of STEM in university classrooms by bridging cultural divides between students and their teachers.

The CANAR system will be constructed using an iterative design methodology, and will build on prior personal informatics software which uses the area under the receiver operating characteristics curve (AUROC) to do speaker-detection on speech in classroom settings. This data will be used to present TAs with a dashboard based on Liddicoat's model of developing intercultural competence. Research will be conducted using qualitative observation and Corbin and Strauss' approach to grounded theory to address questions of what data and strategies can support intercultural noticing and reflection among the TAs, and to examine the benefits of this reflection on their intercultural communication competencies in the classroom. To examine what types of data are helpful for intercultural competence, research participants will engage with three types of data in the CANAR dashboard: artificially synthesized data representing typical experiences by international TAs, real data on the participants' communication derived from human coded observations, and real data on the communication derived by the automated system.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this grant, we conducted work under three major activities: qualitative observational and interview studies to understand the current state of the world with respect to teaching assistants as novice instructors in American undergraduate classrooms, design-based research studies and technology development for approaches incorporating personal informatics into professional development opportunities for such instructors, and design-based research studies and technology development for approaches incorporating just-in-time professional development opportunities.

First, to examine cultural challenges that international teaching assistants (ITAs) encounter we interviewed and observed 20 TAs of multiple cultural backgrounds teaching. Our analysis found that the most significant cultural difference ITAs encountered related to the significantly higher amount of participation expected of students in American classrooms.

From these findings, we explored how personal informatics approaches could help TAs notice and reflect on their teaching practices by looking at data visualizations of their classroom actions. We found that TAs wanted to see visualizations of their personal data, and were able to notice features of their classroom practice that they wished to improve. We found ITA interest in only one main strategy to increase student participation: to increase the amount of time they spent waiting after asking questions. Over a semester, we found that just noticing their own long speaking times and reflecting on the strategy of wait time did not positively affect the actual wait time of the TAs. In both of these studies, we found TAs became discouraged by feeling ineffective in making the progress they desired. This phase demonstrated that while reflecting on personal data may be effective to support a change in a specific behavior, this approach is insufficient if learners do not have the pedagogical content knowledge to successfully implement a new strategy in a social environment.

Our next study explored just-in-time professional development on question asking. Although the training was not required, each week we found over 80% completion. Using the system, our observations showed positive changes in TAs questioning behaviors between baseline and training weeks. On average, TAs posed 36% more questions during training including an increase of 47% for open-ended, deep questions, and a reduction of 17% in asking “any questions?” Our training also covered tactics from the literature to successfully generate student responses, including two that our prior research had found TAs would be unlikely to adopt: use of student names and the practice of cold-calling students. We found our TAs did adopt both of these strategies after training. This effort had some effect; for classes with the fewest student speech events early in the semester, we found a trend that per-student speech events increased as the intervention proceeded.

With this work we formulated a general framework for technology-supported TA development in which we situated our system design to 1) gather meaningful data, 2) provide direct, personal feedback on that data, 3) support reflection including access to evidence for discursive practices, and 4) suggest concrete goals for improving performance in coming classes. We further postulate that it will be necessary for ITAs to shift toward student-centered beliefs, not just practices. Achieving this belief change will first require TAs to have or develop grounded self-efficacy for these new teaching practices.

In a design-based research study with the app we designed from this framework, ClassInsight, TAs received a module within about 1 hour of teaching their class to get direct access to relevant, concrete data. We saw that those who used the app were more likely to implement discursive teaching strategies than those who never used it. We found TAs who saw data that challenged their pre-data-exposure self-assessment made more conscious efforts to improve. Their performance increased overall, and in the end they had higher self-efficacy than before the study. In cases where TAs saw data showing they were doing better than they had expected, there was either no change, or a decrease, in self-efficacy.

As an outcome of this work, we have also conducted socio-technical system development, including improved speaker detection and additional automation for proving teacher data in online training modules. We advanced our technical exploration with visual data collection. This process detects faces of students and the instructor, and produces various types of facial data. One of the simplest and most compelling of these data describes where people look. This piece of information is compelling because of the potential for showing TAs how much time they spend looking at their students, something that our field notes show to be far too low on average. This particular exploration is additionally interesting given that there is no practical way for human coders to track facial direction or gesture, therefore reinforcing the added value of using sensors in classrooms beyond the traditional methods of instructor development by providing expert human observations. We have produced a prototype system that has been deployed in dozens of classrooms.
